questions.question: The two words most often used by economists are
options: prices and quantities.
resources and allocation.
supply and demand.
efficiency and equity.
questions.answer: supply and demand.

questions.question: The two words economists use most often are
options: inflation and trade.
supply and demand.
competition and prices.
markets and equilibrium.
questions.answer: supply and demand.

questions.question: The forces that make market economies work are
options: work and leisure.
politics and religion.
supply and demand.
taxes and government spending.
questions.answer: supply and demand.

questions.question: In a market economy, supply and demand determine
options: both the quantity of each good produced and the price at which it is sold.
the quantity of each good produced but not the price at which it is sold.
the price at which each good is sold but not the quantity of each good produced.
neither the quantity of each good produced nor the price at which it is sold.
questions.answer: both the quantity of each good produced and the price at which it is sold.

questions.question: In a market economy, supply and demand are important because they
options: play a critical role in the allocation of the economy's scarce resources.
determine how much of each good gets produced.
can be used to predict the impact on the economy of various events and policies.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: All of the above are correct.

questions.question: In a market economy, supply and demand are important because they
options: are direct policy tools used by government agencies to regulate the economy.
illustrate when an market is in equilibrium, but they are not helpful when a market is out of equilibrium.
can be used to predict the impact on the economy of various events and policies.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: can be used to predict the impact on the economy of various events and policies.

questions.question: In a market economy,
options: supply determines demand and demand, in turn, determines prices.
demand determines supply and supply, in turn, determines prices.
the allocation of scarce resources determines prices and prices, in turn, determine supply and demand.
supply and demand determine prices and prices, in turn, allocate the economy's scarce resources.
questions.answer: supply and demand determine prices and prices, in turn, allocate the economy's scarce resources.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
options: Buyers determine supply, and sellers determine demand.
Buyers determine demand, and sellers determine supply.
Buyers determine both demand and supply.
Sellers determine both demand and supply.
questions.answer: Buyers determine demand, and sellers determine supply.

questions.question: The demand for a good or service is determined by
options: those who buy the good or service.
the government.
those who sell the good or service.
both those who buy and those who sell the good or service.
questions.answer: those who buy the good or service.

questions.question: The supply of a good or service is determined by
options: those who buy the good or service.
the government.
those who sell the good or service.
both those who buy and those who sell the good or service.
questions.answer: those who sell the good or service.

questions.question: A group of buyers and sellers of a particular good or service is called a(n)
options: coalition.
economy.
market.
competition.
questions.answer: market.

questions.question: For a market for a good or service to exist, there must be a
options: group of buyers and sellers.
specific time and place at which the good or service is traded.
high degree of organization present.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: group of buyers and sellers.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a market?
options: a gas station
a garage sale
a barber shop
All of the above are examples of markets.
questions.answer: All of the above are examples of markets.

questions.question: The market for ice cream is a
options: monopolistic market.
highly competitive market.
highly organized market.
Both b) and c) are correct.
questions.answer: highly competitive market.

questions.question: Most markets in the economy are
options: markets in which sellers, rather than buyers, control the price of the product.
markets in which buyers, rather than sellers, control the price of the product.
perfectly competitive.
highly competitive.
questions.answer: highly competitive.

questions.question: A market includes
options: buyers only.
sellers only.
both buyers and sellers.
the place where transactions occur but not the people involved.
questions.answer: both buyers and sellers.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a market?
options: A small town has only one seller of electricity.
In the United States, a sick person cannot legally purchase a kidney.
In Florida, there are many buyers and sellers of key lime pie.
The availability of Internet shopping has expanded the clothing choices for buyers who do not live near large cities.
questions.answer: In the United States, a sick person cannot legally purchase a kidney.

questions.question: In a competitive market, the price of a product
options: is determined by buyers, and the quantity of the product produced is determined by sellers.
is determined by sellers, and the quantity of the product produced is determined by buyers.
and the quantity of the product produced are both determined by sellers.
None of the above is correct.
questions.answer: None of the above is correct.

questions.question: In a competitive market, the quantity of a product produced and the price of the product are determined by
options: buyers.
sellers.
both buyers and sellers.
None of the above is correct.
questions.answer: both buyers and sellers.

questions.question: In a competitive market, the quantity of a product produced and the price of the product are determined by
options: a single buyer.
a single seller.
one buyer and one seller working together.
all buyers and all sellers.
questions.answer: all buyers and all sellers.

questions.question: A competitive market is a market in which
options: an auctioneer helps set prices and arrange sales.
there are only a few sellers.
the forces of supply and demand do not apply.
no individual buyer or seller has any significant impact on the market price.
questions.answer: no individual buyer or seller has any significant impact on the market price.

questions.question: A competitive market is one in which there
options: is only one seller, but there are many buyers.
are many sellers, and each seller has the ability to set the price of his product.
are many sellers, and they compete with one another in such a way that some sellers are always being forced out of the market.
are so many buyers and so many sellers that each has a negligible impact on the price of the product.
questions.answer: are so many buyers and so many sellers that each has a negligible impact on the price of the product.

questions.question: Assume Diana buys computers in a competitive market. It follows that
options: Diana has a limited number of sellers to turn to when she buys a computer.
Diana will find herself negotiating with sellers whenever she buys a computer.
if Diana buys a large number of computers, the price of computers will rise noticeably.
None of the above is correct.
questions.answer: None of the above is correct.

questions.question: In a competitive market, each seller has limited control over the price of his product because
options: other sellers are offering similar products.
buyers exert more control over the price than do sellers.
these markets are highly regulated by the government.
sellers usually agree to set a common price that will allow each seller to earn a comfortable profit.
questions.answer: other sellers are offering similar products.

questions.question: For a competitive market,
options: a seller can always increase her profit by raising the price of her product.
if a seller charges more than the going price, buyers will go elsewhere to make their purchases.
a seller often charges less than the going price to increase sales and profit.
a single buyer can influence the price of the product but only when purchasing from several sellers in a short period of time.
questions.answer: if a seller charges more than the going price, buyers will go elsewhere to make their purchases.

questions.question: If a seller in a competitive market chooses to charge more than the going price, then
options: the sellers' profits must increase.
the owners of the raw materials used in production would raise the prices for the raw materials.
other sellers would also raise their prices.
buyers will make purchases from other sellers.
questions.answer: buyers will make purchases from other sellers.

questions.question: In competitive markets, buyers
options: are price takers, but sellers are price setters.
are price setters, but sellers are price takers.
and sellers are price takers.
and sellers are price setters.
questions.answer: and sellers are price takers.

questions.question: The term price takers refers to buyers and sellers in
options: perfectly competitive markets.
monopolistic markets.
markets that are regulated by the government.
markets in which buyers cannot buy all they want and/or sellers cannot sell all they want.
questions.answer: perfectly competitive markets.

questions.question: In competitive markets,
options: firms produce identical products.
no individual buyer can influence the market price.
no individual seller can influence the market price.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: All of the above are correct.

questions.question: In competitive markets, which of the following is not correct?
options: Firms produce identical products.
No individual buyer can influence the market price.
Some sellers can set prices.
Buyers are price takers.
questions.answer: Some sellers can set prices.

questions.question: In competitive markets,
options: firms produce identical products.
buyers can influence the market price more easily than sellers.
markets are more likely to be in equilibrium.
sellers are price setters.
questions.answer: firms produce identical products.

questions.question: The highest form of competition is called
options: absolute competition.
cutthroat competition.
perfect competition.
market competition.
questions.answer: perfect competition.

questions.question: The highest form of competition is called
options: arbitrage.
monopolistic competition.
equilibrium.
perfect competition.
questions.answer: perfect competition.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a characteristic of a perfectly competitive market?
options: Different sellers sell identical products.
There are many sellers.
Sellers must accept the price the market determines.
All of the above are characteristics of a perfectly competitive market.
questions.answer: All of the above are characteristics of a perfectly competitive market.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a characteristic of a perfectly competitive market?
options: Sellers set the price of the product.
There are many sellers.
Buyers must accept the price the market determines.
All of the above are characteristics of a perfectly competitive market.
questions.answer: Sellers set the price of the product.

questions.question: Buyers and sellers who have no influence on market price are referred to as
options: market pawns.
monopolists.
price takers.
price setters.
questions.answer: price takers.

questions.question: When all market participants are price takers who have no influence over prices, the markets have
options: only a few buyers and sellers.
numerous sellers but only a few buyers.
numerous buyers but only a few sellers.
numerous buyers and sellers.
questions.answer: numerous buyers and sellers.

questions.question: If buyers and sellers in a certain market are price takers, then individually
options: they have no influence on market price.
they have some influence on market price but that influence is limited.
buyers will be able to find prices lower than those determined in the market.
sellers will find it difficult to sell all they want to sell at the market price.
questions.answer: they have no influence on market price.

questions.question: In a perfectly competitive market, at the market price, buyers
options: cannot buy all they want, and sellers cannot sell all they want.
cannot buy all they want, but sellers can sell all they want.
can buy all they want, but sellers cannot sell all they want.
can buy all they want, and sellers can sell all they want.
questions.answer: can buy all they want, and sellers can sell all they want.

questions.question: An example of a perfectly competitive market would be the
options: cable TV market.
soybean market.
breakfast cereal market.
shampoo market.
questions.answer: soybean market.

questions.question: An example of a perfectly competitive market would be the market for
options: tennis racquets.
pizza.
garbage collection.
wheat.
questions.answer: wheat.

questions.question: An example of a perfectly competitive market would be the market for
options: electricity.
soybeans.
coffee shops.
restaurants.
questions.answer: soybeans.

questions.question: Which of the following is the least likely to be a competitive market?
options: ice cream
soybeans
cable television
new houses
questions.answer: cable television

questions.question: Assume the market for tennis balls is perfectly competitive. When one tennis ball producer exits the market,
options: the price of tennis balls increases.
the price of tennis balls decreases.
the price of tennis balls does not change.
there is no longer a market for tennis balls.
questions.answer: the price of tennis balls does not change.

questions.question: Assume the market for pork is perfectly competitive. When one pork buyer exits the market,
options: the price of pork increases.
the price of pork decreases.
the price of pork does not change.
there is no longer a market for pork.
questions.answer: the price of pork does not change.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a reason perfect competition is a useful simplification, despite the diversity of market types we find in the world?
options: Perfectly competitive markets are the easiest to analyze because everyone participating in the market takes the price as given by market conditions.
Some degree of competition is present in most markets.
There are many buyers and many sellers in all types of markets.
Many of the lessons that we learn by studying supply and demand under perfect competition apply in more complicated markets as well.
questions.answer: There are many buyers and many sellers in all types of markets.

questions.question: If a firm is a price taker, it operates in a
options: competitive market.
monopoly market.
oligopoly market.
monopolistically competitive market.
questions.answer: competitive market.

questions.question: A monopoly is a market with one
options: seller, and that seller is a price taker.
seller, and that seller sets the price.
buyer, and that buyer is a price taker.
buyer, and that buyer sets the price.
questions.answer: seller, and that seller sets the price.

questions.question: Which of the following would most likely serve as an example of a monopoly?
options: a bakery in a large city
a bank in a large city
a local cable television company
a small group of corn farmers
questions.answer: a local cable television company

questions.question: Which of the following would most likely serve as an example of a monopoly?
options: a restaurant in a large city
a dry cleaners in a large city
a local gas station
a local electrical company
questions.answer: a local electrical company

questions.question: The quantity demanded of a good is the amount that buyers are
options: willing to purchase.
willing and able to purchase.
willing, able, and need to purchase.
able to purchase.
questions.answer: willing and able to purchase.

questions.question: An increase in quantity demanded
options: results in a movement downward and to the right along a demand curve.
results in a movement upward and to the left along a demand curve.
shifts the demand curve to the left.
shifts the demand curve to the right.
questions.answer: results in a movement downward and to the right along a demand curve.

questions.question: A decrease in quantity demanded
options: results in a movement downward and to the right along a demand curve.
results in a movement upward and to the left along a demand curve.
shifts the demand curve to the left.
shifts the demand curve to the right.
questions.answer: results in a movement upward and to the left along a demand curve.

questions.question: A movement upward and to the left along a demand curve is called a(n)
options: increase in demand.
decrease in demand.
decrease in quantity demanded.
increase in quantity demanded.
questions.answer: decrease in quantity demanded.

questions.question: A movement downward and to the right along a demand curve is called a(n)
options: increase in demand.
decrease in demand.
decrease in quantity demanded.
increase in quantity demanded.
questions.answer: increase in quantity demanded.

questions.question: An increase in the price of a good will
options: increase demand.
decrease demand.
increase quantity demanded.
decrease quantity demanded.
questions.answer: decrease quantity demanded.

questions.question: A decrease in the price of a good will
options: increase demand.
decrease demand.
increase quantity demanded.
decrease quantity demanded.
questions.answer: increase quantity demanded.

questions.question: When the price of a good or service changes,
options: the supply curve shifts in the opposite direction.
the demand curve shifts in the opposite direction.
the demand curve shifts in the same direction.
there is a movement along a given demand curve.
questions.answer: there is a movement along a given demand curve.

questions.question: A decrease in the price of a good would
options: increase the supply of the good.
increase the quantity demanded of the good.
give producers an incentive to produce more to keep profits from falling.
shift the supply curve for the good to the left.
questions.answer: increase the quantity demanded of the good.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-1. The movement from point A to point B on the graph shows
options: a decrease in demand.
an increase in demand.
a decrease in quantity demanded.
an increase in quantity demanded.
questions.answer: an increase in quantity demanded.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-1. The movement from point A to point B on the graph is caused by
options: an increase in price.
a decrease in price.
a decrease in the price of a substitute good.
an increase in income.
questions.answer: a decrease in price.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-1. It is apparent from the figure that the
options: good is inferior.
demand for the good decreases as income increases.
demand for the good conforms to the law of demand.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: demand for the good conforms to the law of demand.

questions.question: "Other things equal, when the price of a good rises, the quantity demanded of the good falls, and when the price falls, the quantity demanded rises." This relationship between price and quantity demanded
options: applies to most goods in the economy.
is represented by a downward-sloping demand curve.
is referred to as the law of demand.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: All of the above are correct.

questions.question: "Other things equal, when the price of a good rises, the quantity demanded of the good falls, and when the price falls, the quantity demanded rises." This relationship between price and quantity demanded is referred to as
options: equilibrium.
the law of demand.
the relationship between supply and demand.
the definition of an inferior good.
questions.answer: the law of demand.

questions.question: The law of demand states that, other things equal, when the price of a good
options: falls, the demand for the good rises.
rises, the quantity demanded of the good rises.
rises, the demand for the good falls.
falls, the quantity demanded of the good rises.
questions.answer: falls, the quantity demanded of the good rises.

questions.question: The law of demand states that, other things equal, an increase in
options: price causes quantity demanded to increase.
price causes quantity demanded to decrease.
quantity demanded causes price to increase.
quantity demanded causes price to decrease.
questions.answer: price causes quantity demanded to decrease.

questions.question: Which of these statements best represents the law of demand?
options: When buyers' tastes for a good increase, they purchase more of the good.
When income levels increase, buyers purchase more of most goods.
When the price of a good decreases, buyers purchase more of the good.
When buyers' demands for a good increase, the price of the good increases.
questions.answer: When the price of a good decreases, buyers purchase more of the good.

questions.question: A downward-sloping demand curve illustrates
options: that demand decreases over time.
that prices fall over time.
the relationship between income and quantity demanded.
the law of demand.
questions.answer: the law of demand.

questions.question: Nemo rents 5 movies per month when the price is $3.00 per rental and 7 movies per month when the price is $2.50 per rental. Nemo's demand demonstrates the law of
options: price.
supply.
demand.
income.
questions.answer: demand.

questions.question: Which of the following demonstrates the law of demand?
options: After Jon got a raise at work, he bought more pretzels at $1.50 per pretzel than he did before his raise.
Melissa buys fewer muffins at $0.75 per muffin than at $1 per muffin, other things equal.
Dave buys more donuts at $0.25 per donut than at $0.50 per donut, other things equal.
Kendra buys fewer Snickers at $0.60 per Snickers after the price of Milky Ways falls to $0.50 per Milky Way.
questions.answer: Dave buys more donuts at $0.25 per donut than at $0.50 per donut, other things equal.

questions.question: The following table contains a demand schedule for a good. Price Quantity Demanded $10 100 $20 Q1 If the law of demand applies to this good, then Q1 could be

If the price of apple pies rose to $100 per pie, consumers would purchase fewer pies than if the price were $5 per pie. If the price of ice cream fell to $0.30 per scoop, consumers would purchase more ice cream than if the price were $5 per scoop. These relationships illustrate the
options: law of demand.
law of supply.
difference between normal and inferior goods.
difference between substitute and complement goods.
questions.answer: law of demand.

questions.question: A table that shows the relationship between the price of a good and the quantity demanded of that good is called a
options: price-quantity schedule.
buyer schedule.
demand schedule.
demand curve.
questions.answer: demand schedule.

questions.question: A demand schedule is a table that shows the relationship between
options: quantity demanded and quantity supplied.
income and quantity demanded.
price and quantity demanded.
price and income.
questions.answer: price and quantity demanded.

questions.question: Which of the following is not held constant in a demand schedule?
options: income
tastes
price
expectations
questions.answer: price

questions.question: The demand curve for a good is a line that relates
options: price and quantity demanded.
income and quantity demanded.
quantity demanded and quantity supplied.
price and income.
questions.answer: price and quantity demanded.

questions.question: The line that relates the price of a good and the quantity demanded of that good is called the demand
options: schedule, and it usually slopes upward.
schedule, and it usually slopes downward.
curve, and it usually slopes upward.
curve, and it usually slopes downward.
questions.answer: curve, and it usually slopes downward.

questions.question: When drawing a demand curve,
options: demand is measured along the vertical axis, and price is measured along the horizontal axis.
quantity demanded is measured along the vertical axis, and price is measured along the horizontal axis.
price is measured along the vertical axis, and demand is measured along the horizontal axis.
price is measured along the vertical axis, and quantity demanded is measured along the horizontal axis.
questions.answer: price is measured along the vertical axis, and quantity demanded is measured along the horizontal axis.

questions.question: When we move along a given demand curve,
options: only price is held constant.
income and price are held constant.
all nonprice determinants of demand are held constant.
all determinants of quantity demanded are held constant.
questions.answer: all nonprice determinants of demand are held constant.

questions.question: Once the demand curve for a product or service is drawn, it
options: remains stable over time.
can shift either rightward or leftward.
is possible to move along the curve, but the curve will not shift.
tends to become steeper over time.
questions.answer: can shift either rightward or leftward.

questions.question: If something happens to alter the quantity demanded at any given price, then
options: the demand curve becomes steeper.
the demand curve becomes flatter.
the demand curve shifts.
we move along the demand curve.
questions.answer: the demand curve shifts.

questions.question: When quantity demanded decreases at every possible price, the demand curve has
options: shifted to the left.
shifted to the right.
not shifted; rather, we have moved along the demand curve to a new point on the same curve.
not shifted; rather, the demand curve has become flatter.
questions.answer: shifted to the left.

questions.question: When quantity demanded increases at every possible price, the demand curve has
options: shifted to the left.
shifted to the right.
not shifted; rather, we have moved along the demand curve to a new point on the same curve.
not shifted; rather, the demand curve has become steeper.
questions.answer: shifted to the right.

questions.question: The market demand curve
options: is found by vertically adding the individual demand curves.
slopes upward.
represents the sum of the prices that all the buyers are willing to pay for a given quantity of the good.
represents the sum of the quantities demanded by all the buyers at each price of the good.
questions.answer: represents the sum of the quantities demanded by all the buyers at each price of the good.

questions.question: The market demand curve
options: is the sum of all individual demand curves.
is the demand curve for every product in an industry.
shows the average quantity demanded by individual demanders at each price.
is always flatter than an individual demand curve.
questions.answer: is the sum of all individual demand curves.

questions.question: To obtain the market demand curve for a product, sum the individual demand curves
options: vertically.
diagonally.
horizontally.
and then average them.
questions.answer: horizontally.

questions.question: A market demand curve shows
options: the relationship between price and the number of buyers in a market.
how quantity demanded changes when the number of sellers changes.
the sum of all prices that individual buyers are willing and able to pay for each possible quantity of the good.
how much of a good all buyers are willing and able to buy at each possible price.
questions.answer: how much of a good all buyers are willing and able to buy at each possible price.

questions.question: A market demand curve shows how the total quantity demanded of a good varies as
options: income varies.
price varies.
price of the nearest substitute good varies.
supply varies.
questions.answer: price varies.

questions.question: Refer to Table 4-1. If the market consists of Michelle, Laura, and Hillary and the price falls by $1, the quantity demanded in the market increases by
options: 2 units.
3 units.
4 units.
5 units.
questions.answer: 5 units.

questions.question: Refer to Table 4-1. If the market consists of Michelle and Laura only and the price falls by $1, the quantity demanded in the market increases by
options: 2 units.
3 units.
4 units.
5 units.
questions.answer: 3 units.

questions.question: Refer to Table 4-1. If the market consists of Michelle and Hillary only and the price falls by $1, the quantity demanded in the market increases by
options: 2 units.
3 units.
4 units.
5 units.
questions.answer: 3 units.

questions.question: Refer to Table 4-1. If the market consists of Laura and Hillary only and the price falls by $1, the quantity demanded in the market increases by
options: 2 units.
3 units.
4 units.
5 units.
questions.answer: 4 units.

questions.question: Refer to Table 4-1. Which of the following illustrates the market demand curve? Price Price 5 4 4 3 3 2 2 1 1 Demand C Demand A 2 4 6 8 10 12 5 Quantity Price 15 20 25 10 15 20 25 30 35 40 45 Quantity Price 5 10 5 4 4 3 3 2 2 1 1 Demand B 4
Refer to Figure 4-2. If Consumer A and Consumer B are the only consumers in the market, then the market quantity demanded when the price is $6 is
options: 4 units.
6 units.
8 units.
12 units.
questions.answer: 12 units.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-2. If Consumer A and Consumer B are the only consumers in the market, then the market quantity demanded when the price is $10 is
options: 0 units.
4 units.
10 units.
12 units.
questions.answer: 4 units.

questions.question: Refer to Table 4-2. Whose demand does not obey the law of demand?
options: William's
Fergie's
Taboo's
apl.de.ap's
questions.answer: Taboo's

questions.question: Refer to Table 4-2. If these are the only four buyers in the market, then the market quantity demanded at a price of $8 is
options: 4 units.
6 units.
24 units.
32 units.
questions.answer: 24 units.

questions.question: Refer to Table 4-2. If these are the only four buyers in the market, then when the price decreases from $6 to $4, the market quantity demanded
options: increases by 0.75 units.
increases by 3 units.
increases by 8 units.
decreases by 27 units.
questions.answer: increases by 3 units.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-3. If these are the only two consumers in the market, then the market quantity demanded at a price of $15 is
options: 0 units.
10 units.
15 units.
25 units.
questions.answer: 0 units.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-3. If these are the only two consumers in the market, then the market quantity demanded at a price of $10 is
options: 0 units.
5 units.
8.33 units.
25 units.
questions.answer: 8.33 units.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-3. If these are the only two consumers in the market, then the market quantity demanded at a price of $6 is
options: 12 units.
14 units.
19 units.
21 units.
questions.answer: 19 units.

questions.question: Suppose Spencer and Kate are the only two demanders of lemonade. Each month, Spencer buys six glasses of lemonade when the price is $1.00 per glass, and he buys four glasses when the price is $1.50 per glass. Each month, Kate buys four glasses of lemonade when the price is $1.00 per glass, and she buys two glasses when the price is $1.50 per glass. Which of the following points is on the market demand curve?
options: (quantity demanded = 2, price = $1.50)
(quantity demanded = 4, price = $2.50)
(quantity demanded = 10, price = $1.00)
(quantity demanded = 16, price = $2.50)
questions.answer: (quantity demanded = 10, price = $1.00)

questions.question: Suppose Spencer and Kate are the only two demanders of lemonade. Each month, Spencer buys six glasses of lemonade when the price is $1.00 per glass, and he buys four glasses when the price is $1.50 per glass. Each month, Kate buys four glasses of lemonade when the price is $1.00 per glass, and she buys two glasses when the price is $1.50 per glass. Which of the following points is on the market demand curve? Point Price Quantity A $1.00 4 B $1.00 10 C $1.50 2 D $1.50 6
options: B only
B and D only
A and C only
D only
questions.answer: B and D only

questions.question: Refer to Table 4-3. Whose demand does not obey the law of demand?
options: Bert's
Ernie's
Grover's
Oscar's
questions.answer: Grover's

questions.question: Refer to Table 4-3. If these are the only four buyers in the market, then the market quantity demanded at a price of $1 is
options: 4 units.
7.75 units.
14 units.
31 units.
questions.answer: 31 units.

questions.question: Refer to Table 4-3. If these are the only four buyers in the market, then the market quantity demanded at a price of $2 is
options: 0 units.
3.5 units.
12 units.
14 units.
questions.answer: 14 units.

questions.question: Refer to Table 4-3. If these are the only four buyers in the market, then when the price increases from $1.00 to $1.50, the market quantity demanded
options: decreases by 1.75 units.
increases by 2 units.
decreases by 7 units.
decreases by 24 units.
questions.answer: decreases by 7 units.

questions.question: Refer to Table 4-3. For whom is the good a normal good?
options: Bert only
Grover only
Bert, Ernie, Grover, and Oscar
This cannot be determined from the table.
questions.answer: This cannot be determined from the table.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-4. Which of the following would cause the demand curve to shift from Demand B to Demand C in the market for DVDs in the United States?
options: a decrease in the price of DVDs
a decrease in the price of DVD players
a change in consumer preferences toward watching movies in movie theaters rather than at home
a decrease in the number of people in the United States
questions.answer: a decrease in the price of DVD players

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-4. Which of the following would cause the demand curve to shift from Demand C to Demand A in the market for DVDs?
options: an increase in the price of DVDs
a decrease in the price of DVD players
a change in consumer preferences toward watching movies in movie theaters rather than at home
an expectation by buyers that their incomes will increase in the very near future
questions.answer: a change in consumer preferences toward watching movies in movie theaters rather than at home

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-4. Which of the following would cause the demand curve to shift from Demand C to Demand A in the market for tennis balls in the United States?
options: an increase in the price of tennis balls
a decrease in the price of tennis racquets
an expectation by buyers that their incomes will increase in the very near future
a decrease in the number of people in the United States under age 70
questions.answer: a decrease in the number of people in the United States under age 70

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-4. Which of the following would cause the demand curve to shift from Demand A to Demand B in the market for golf balls in the United States?
options: a decrease in the price of golf balls
an increase in the price of green fees
an expectation by buyers that their incomes will increase in the very near future
a change in consumer tastes away from golf and toward tennis
questions.answer: an expectation by buyers that their incomes will increase in the very near future

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-4. Which of the following would cause the demand curve to shift from Demand A to Demand B in the market for oranges in the United States?
options: a freeze in Florida
a technological advance that allows oranges to ripen faster
a decrease in the price of apples
an announcement by the FDA that oranges prevent heart disease
questions.answer: an announcement by the FDA that oranges prevent heart disease

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-5. Suppose that the federal government is concerned about obesity in the United States. Congress is considering two plans. One would require "junk food" producers to include warning labels on all junk food. The other would impose a tax on all products considered to be junk food. If the warning labels are successful, we could illustrate the plan as producing a movement from
options: Point A to Point B in Panel 1.
Point B to Point A in Panel 1.
Point A to Point C in Panel 2.
Point C to Point A in Panel 2.
questions.answer: Point A to Point B in Panel 1.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-5. Suppose that the federal government is concerned about obesity in the United States. Congress is considering two plans. One would require "junk food" producers to include warning labels on all junk food. The other would impose a tax on all products considered to be junk food. We could illustrate the tax as producing a movement from
options: Point A to Point B in Panel 1.
Point B to Point A in Panel 1.
Point A to Point C in Panel 2.
Point C to Point A in Panel 2.
questions.answer: Point A to Point C in Panel 2.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-6. The shift from D to D' is called
options: an increase in demand.
a decrease in demand.
a decrease in quantity demanded.
an increase in quantity demanded.
questions.answer: a decrease in demand.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-6. If the demand curve shifts from D to D', then
options: firms would be willing to supply less of the good than before at each possible price.
people are willing to buy less of the good than before at each possible price.
people's incomes must have decreased.
the price of the product has increased, causing consumers to buy less of the product.
questions.answer: people are willing to buy less of the good than before at each possible price.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-6. The movement from D to D' could be caused by
options: an increase in price.
a decrease in the price of a complement.
a technological advance.
a decrease in the price of a substitute.
questions.answer: a decrease in the price of a substitute.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-6. The movement from D' to D could be caused by
options: a decrease in price.
a decrease in income, assuming the good is inferior.
buyers expecting the price of the good to fall in the near future.
an increase in the price of a complement.
questions.answer: a decrease in income, assuming the good is inferior.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-6. The movement from D' to D in the market for potato chips could be caused by a(n)
options: decrease in the price of potato chips.
decrease in income, assuming that potato chips are a normal good.
announcement by the FDA that potato chips cause cancer.
increase in the price of a pretzels.
questions.answer: increase in the price of a pretzels.

questions.question: An increase in demand is represented by a
options: movement downward and to the right along a demand curve.
movement upward and to the left along a demand curve.
rightward shift of a demand curve.
leftward shift of a demand curve.
questions.answer: rightward shift of a demand curve.

questions.question: A decrease in demand is represented by a
options: movement downward and to the right along a demand curve.
movement upward and to the left along a demand curve.
rightward shift of a demand curve.
leftward shift of a demand curve.
questions.answer: leftward shift of a demand curve.

questions.question: A leftward shift of a demand curve is called a(n)
options: increase in demand.
decrease in demand.
decrease in quantity demanded.
increase in quantity demanded.
questions.answer: decrease in demand.

questions.question: A rightward shift of a demand curve is called a(n)
options: increase in demand.
decrease in demand.
decrease in quantity demanded.
increase in quantity demanded.
questions.answer: increase in demand.

questions.question: If buyers today become more willing and able than before to purchase larger quantities of Vanilla Coke at each price of Vanilla Coke, then
options: we will observe a movement downward and to the right along the demand curve for Vanilla Coke.
we will observe a movement upward and to the left along the demand curve for Vanilla Coke.
the demand curve for Vanilla Coke will shift to the right.
the demand curve for Vanilla Coke will shift to the left.
questions.answer: the demand curve for Vanilla Coke will shift to the right.

questions.question: When the price of hot dogs changes, the demand curve for hot dogs
options: shifts because the price of hot dogs is measured on the vertical axis of the graph.
shifts because the quantity demanded of hot dogs is measured on the horizontal axis of the graph.
does not shift because the price of hot dogs is measured on the vertical axis of the graph.
does not shift because the price of hot dogs is measured on the horizontal axis of the graph.
questions.answer: does not shift because the price of hot dogs is measured on the vertical axis of the graph.

questions.question: Which of the following changes would not shift the demand curve for a good or service?
options: a change in income
a change in the price of the good or service
a change in expectations about the future price of the good or service
a change in the price of a related good or service
questions.answer: a change in the price of the good or service

questions.question: Which of the following would not shift the demand curve for mp3 players?
options: a decrease in the price of mp3 players
a fad that makes mp3 players more popular among 12-25 year olds
an increase in the price of digital music downloads, a complement for mp3 players
a decrease in the price of satellite radio, a substitute for mp3 players
questions.answer: a decrease in the price of mp3 players

questions.question: Which of the following events would cause a movement upward and to the left along the demand curve for olives?
options: The number of people who purchase olives decreases.
Consumer income decreases, and olives are a normal good.
The price of pickles decreases, and pickles are a substitute for olives.
The price of olives rises.
questions.answer: The price of olives rises.

questions.question: A movement along the demand curve might be caused by a change in
options: income.
the prices of substitutes or complements.
expectations about future prices.
the price of the good or service that is being demanded.
questions.answer: the price of the good or service that is being demanded.

questions.question: Holding the nonprice determinants of demand constant, a change in price would
options: result in either a decrease in demand or an increase in demand.
result in a movement along a stationary demand curve.
result in a shift of supply.
have no effect on the quantity demanded.
questions.answer: result in a movement along a stationary demand curve.

questions.question: The sum of all the individual demand curves for a product is called
options: income demand.
equilibrium demand.
complementary demand.
market demand.
questions.answer: market demand.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an expression for the sum of all the individual demand curves for a product?
options: total demand
market demand
equilibrium demand
aggregate demand
questions.answer: equilibrium demand

questions.question: The demand curve for textbooks shifts
options: only when income changes.
when a determinant of the demand for textbooks other than the price of textbooks changes.
when the price of textbooks changes.
Both b) and c) are correct.
questions.answer: when a determinant of the demand for textbooks other than the price of textbooks changes.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a determinant of the demand for a particular good?
options: the prices of related goods
income
tastes
the prices of the inputs used to produce the good
questions.answer: the prices of the inputs used to produce the good

questions.question: Each of the following is a determinant of demand except
options: tastes.
production technology.
expectations.
the prices of related goods.
questions.answer: production technology.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a determinant of demand?
options: the price of a resource that is used to produce the good
the price of a complementary good
the price of the good next month
the price of a substitute good
questions.answer: the price of a resource that is used to produce the good

questions.question: If the demand for a good falls when income falls, then the good is called a(n)
options: normal good.
regular good.
luxury good.
inferior good.
questions.answer: normal good.

questions.question: If a good is normal, then an increase in income will result in a(n)
options: increase in the demand for the good.
decrease in the demand for the good.
movement down and to the right along the demand curve for the good.
movement up and to the left along the demand curve for the good.
questions.answer: increase in the demand for the good.

questions.question: If Max experiences a decrease in his income, then we would expect Max's demand for
options: each good he purchases to remain unchanged.
normal goods to decrease.
luxury goods to increase.
inferior goods to decrease.
questions.answer: normal goods to decrease.

questions.question: You lose your job and, as a result, you buy fewer iTunes music downloads. This shows that you consider iTunes music downloads to be a(n)
options: luxury good.
inferior good.
normal good.
complementary good.
questions.answer: normal good.

questions.question: Pizza is a normal good if the demand
options: for pizza rises when income rises.
for pizza rises when the price of pizza falls.
curve for pizza slopes upward.
curve for pizza shifts to the right when the price of burritos rises, assuming pizza and burritos are substitutes.
questions.answer: for pizza rises when income rises.

questions.question: Suppose that when income rises, the demand curve for doctor's visits shifts to the right. In this case, we know doctor's visits are
options: inferior goods.
normal goods.
perfectly competitive goods.
durable goods.
questions.answer: normal goods.

questions.question: Which of the following would shift the demand curve for gasoline to the right?
options: a decrease in the price of gasoline
an increase in consumer income, assuming gasoline is a normal good
an increase in the price of cars, a complement for gasoline
a decrease in the expected future price of gasoline
questions.answer: an increase in consumer income, assuming gasoline is a normal good

questions.question: If a decrease in income increases the demand for a good, then the good is a(n)
options: substitute good.
complementary good.
normal good.
inferior good.
questions.answer: inferior good.

questions.question: If a increase in income decreases the demand for a good, then the good is a(n)
options: substitute good.
complementary good.
normal good.
inferior good.
questions.answer: inferior good.

questions.question: If a good is inferior, then an increase in income will result in
options: an increase in the demand for the good.
a decrease in the demand for the good.
a movement down and to the right along the demand curve for the good.
a movement up and to the left along the demand curve for the good.
questions.answer: a decrease in the demand for the good.

questions.question: Currently you purchase ten frozen pizza per month. You will graduate from college in December, and you will start a new job in January. You have no plans to purchase frozen pizzas in January. For you, frozen pizzas are a(n)
options: substitute good.
normal good.
inferior good.
complementary good.
questions.answer: inferior good.

questions.question: Soup is an inferior good if the demand
options: for soup falls when the price of a substitute for soup rises.
for soup rises when the price of soup falls.
curve for soup slopes upward.
for soup falls when income rises.
questions.answer: for soup falls when income rises.

questions.question: Suppose that Amanda receives a pay increase. We would expect
options: to observe Amanda moving down and to the right along her given demand curve.
Amanda's demand for inferior goods to decrease.
Amanda's demand for each of two goods that are complements to increase.
Amanda's demand for normal goods to decrease.
questions.answer: Amanda's demand for inferior goods to decrease.

questions.question: If macaroni and cheese is an inferior good, then an increase in
options: the price will cause the demand curve for macaroni and cheese to shift to the left.
the price will cause the demand curve for macaroni and cheese to shift to the right.
a consumer's income will cause the demand curve for macaroni and cheese to shift to the left.
a consumer's income will cause the demand curve for macaroni and cheese to shift to the right.
questions.answer: a consumer's income will cause the demand curve for macaroni and cheese to shift to the left.

questions.question: Two goods are substitutes when a decrease in the price of one good
options: decreases the demand for the other good.
decreases the quantity demanded of the other good.
increases the demand for the other good.
increases the quantity demanded of the other good.
questions.answer: decreases the demand for the other good.

questions.question: Suppose that a decrease in the price of good X results in fewer units of good Y being demanded. This implies that X and Y are
options: complementary goods.
normal goods.
inferior goods.
substitute goods.
questions.answer: substitute goods.

questions.question: Good X and good Y are substitutes. If the price of good Y increases, then the
options: demand for good X will decrease.
quantity demanded of good X will decrease.
demand for good X will increase.
quantity demanded of good X will increase.
questions.answer: demand for good X will increase.

questions.question: A likely example of substitute goods for most people would be
options: peanut butter and jelly.
tennis balls and tennis rackets.
televisions and subscriptions to cable television services.
pencils and pens.
questions.answer: pencils and pens.

questions.question: If muffins and bagels are substitutes, a higher price for bagels would result in a(n)
options: increase in the demand for bagels.
decrease in the demand for bagels.
increase in the demand for muffins.
decrease in the demand for muffins.
questions.answer: increase in the demand for muffins.

questions.question: You wear either shorts or sweatpants every day. You notice that sweatpants have gone on sale, so your demand for
options: sweatpants will increase.
sweatpants will decrease.
shorts will increase.
shorts will decrease.
questions.answer: shorts will decrease.

questions.question: If American cheese and cheddar cheese are substitutes, then which of the following would increase the demand for cheddar cheese?
options: a decrease in the price of cheddar cheese
an increase in the price of American cheese
a decrease in the price of American cheese
Both a) and b) are correct.
questions.answer: an increase in the price of American cheese

questions.question: Two goods are complements when a decrease in the price of one good
options: decreases the quantity demanded of the other good.
decreases the demand for the other good.
increases the quantity demanded of the other good.
increases the demand for the other good.
questions.answer: increases the demand for the other good.

questions.question: If goods A and B are complements, then an increase in the price of good A will result in
options: more of good A being sold.
more of good B being sold.
less of good B being sold.
no difference in the quantity sold of either good.
questions.answer: less of good B being sold.

questions.question: A likely example of complementary goods for most people would be
options: butter and margarine.
lawnmowers and automobiles.
chips and salsa.
cola and lemonade.
questions.answer: chips and salsa.

questions.question: A higher price for batteries would result in a(n)
options: increase in the demand for flashlights.
decrease in the demand for flashlights.
increase in the demand for batteries.
decrease in the demand for batteries.
questions.answer: decrease in the demand for flashlights.

questions.question: Suppose you like to make, from scratch, pies filled with banana cream and vanilla pudding. You notice that the price of bananas has increased. As a result, your demand for vanilla pudding would
options: decrease.
increase.
be unaffected.
There is insufficient information given to answer the question.
questions.answer: decrease.

questions.question: Holding all other things constant, a higher price for ski lift tickets would
options: increase the number of skiers.
increase the price of skis.
decrease the number of skis sold.
decrease the demand for other winter recreational activities.
questions.answer: decrease the number of skis sold.

questions.question: When quantity demanded has increased at every price, it might be because
options: the number of buyers in the market has decreased.
income has increased, and the good is an inferior good.
the costs incurred by sellers producing the good have decreased.
the price of a complementary good has decreased.
questions.answer: the price of a complementary good has decreased.

questions.question: Which of the following might cause the demand curve for an inferior good to shift to the left?
options: a decrease in income
an increase in the price of a substitute
an increase in the price of a complement
None of the above is correct.
questions.answer: an increase in the price of a complement

questions.question: If toast and butter are complements, then which of the following would increase the demand for toast?
options: a decrease in the price of toast
a decrease in the price of butter
an increase in the price of butter
Both a) and b) are correct.
questions.answer: a decrease in the price of butter

questions.question: When it comes to people's tastes, economists generally believe that
options: tastes are based on forces that are well within the realm of economics.
tastes are based on historical and psychological forces that are beyond the realm of economics.
tastes can only be studied through well-constructed, real-life models.
because tastes do not directly affect demand, there is little need to explain people's tastes.
questions.answer: tastes are based on historical and psychological forces that are beyond the realm of economics.

questions.question: Economists normally
options: do not try to explain people's tastes, but they do try to explain what happens when tastes change.
believe that they must be able to explain people's tastes in order to explain what happens when tastes change.
do not believe that people's tastes determine demand, so they ignore the subject of tastes.
incorporate tastes into economic models only to the extent that tastes determine whether pairs of goods are substitutes or complements.
questions.answer: do not try to explain people's tastes, but they do try to explain what happens when tastes change.

questions.question: Suppose the American Medical Association announces that men who shave their heads are less likely to die of heart failure. We could expect the current demand for
options: hair gel to increase.
razors to increase.
combs to increase.
shampoo to increase.
questions.answer: razors to increase.

questions.question: Suppose scientists provide evidence that chocolate pudding increases the bad cholesterol levels of those who eat it. We would expect to see
options: no change in the demand for chocolate pudding.
a decrease in the demand for chocolate pudding.
an increase in the demand for chocolate pudding.
a decrease in the supply of chocolate pudding.
questions.answer: a decrease in the demand for chocolate pudding.

questions.question: A very hot summer in Atlanta will cause
options: the demand curve for lemonade to shift to the left.
the demand for air conditioners to decrease.
the demand for jackets to decrease.
a movement downward and to the right along the demand curve for tank tops.
questions.answer: the demand for jackets to decrease.

questions.question: If a study by medical researchers finds that eating brown rice causes weight loss while eating white rice causes weight gain, then we likely would see
options: an increase in demand for brown rice and a decrease in demand for white rice.
a decrease in demand for brown rice and an increase in demand for white rice.
an increase in demand for both brown and white rice.
no change in demand for either type of rice because weight loss is not a determinant of demand.
questions.answer: an increase in demand for brown rice and a decrease in demand for white rice.

questions.question: Which of the following events could shift the demand curve for gasoline to the left?
options: The income of gasoline buyers rises, and gasoline is a normal good.
The income of gasoline buyers falls, and gasoline is an inferior good.
Public service announcements run on television encourage people to walk or ride bicycles instead of driving cars.
The price of gasoline rises.
questions.answer: Public service announcements run on television encourage people to walk or ride bicycles instead of driving cars.

questions.question: An increase in the number of college scholarships issued by private foundations would
options: increase the supply of education.
decrease the supply of education.
increase the demand for education.
decrease the demand for education.
questions.answer: increase the demand for education.

questions.question: Today, people changed their expectations about the future. This change
options: can cause a movement along a demand curve.
can affect future demand but not today's demand.
can affect today's demand.
cannot affect either today's demand or future demand.
questions.answer: can affect today's demand.

questions.question: If Miguel expects to earn a higher income next month, he may choose to
options: save more now and spend less of his current income on goods and services.
save less now and spend more of his current income on goods and services.
decrease his current demand for goods and services.
move along his current demand curves for goods and services.
questions.answer: save less now and spend more of his current income on goods and services.

questions.question: You love peanut butter. You hear on the news that 50 percent of the peanut crop in the South has been wiped out by drought and that this will cause the price of peanuts to double by the end of the year. As a result, your demand for peanut butter
options: will increase but not until the end of the year.
increases today.
decreases as you look for a substitute good.
shifts left today.
questions.answer: increases today.

questions.question: Ford Motor Company announces that next month it will offer $3,000 rebates on new Mustangs. As a result of this information, today's demand curve for Mustangs
options: shifts to the right.
shifts to the left.
shifts either to the right or to the left, but we cannot determine the direction of the shift from the given information.
will not shift; rather, the demand curve for Mustangs will shift to the right next month.
questions.answer: shifts to the left.

questions.question: What will happen in the artichoke market now if buyers expect higher artichoke prices in the near future?
options: The demand for artichokes will increase.
The demand for artichokes will decrease.
The demand for artichokes will be unaffected.
The supply of artichokes will increase.
questions.answer: The demand for artichokes will increase.

questions.question: Today's demand curve for gasoline could shift in response to a change in
options: today's price of gasoline.
the expected future price of gasoline.
the number of sellers of gasoline.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: the expected future price of gasoline.

questions.question: If the number of buyers in a market decreases, then
options: demand will increase.
demand will decrease.
supply will increase.
supply will decrease.
questions.answer: demand will decrease.

questions.question: Which of the following does not affect an individual's demand curve?
options: expectations
income
prices of related goods
the number of buyers
questions.answer: the number of buyers

questions.question: Warrensburg is a small college town in Missouri. At the end of August each year, the market demand for fast food in Warrensburg
options: increases.
decreases.
remains constant, but we observe a movement downward and to the right along the demand curve.
remains constant, but we observe a movement upward and to the left along the demand curve.
questions.answer: increases.

questions.question: For the general population, a 10 percent increase in the price of cigarettes leads to a
options: 1 percent reduction in the quantity demanded of cigarettes.
4 percent reduction in the quantity demanded of cigarettes.
10 percent reduction in the quantity demanded of cigarettes.
12 percent reduction in the quantity demanded of cigarettes.
questions.answer: 4 percent reduction in the quantity demanded of cigarettes.

questions.question: For teenagers, a 10 percent increase in the price of cigarettes leads to a
options: 1 percent reduction in the quantity demanded of cigarettes.
4 percent reduction in the quantity demanded of cigarettes.
10 percent reduction in the quantity demanded of cigarettes.
12 percent reduction in the quantity demanded of cigarettes.
questions.answer: 12 percent reduction in the quantity demanded of cigarettes.

questions.question: The belief that tobacco is a "gateway drug" is consistent with
options: the idea that tobacco and marijuana are substitutes.
the idea that an increase in income causes a decrease in the demand for tobacco and an increase in the demand for marijuana.
the idea that lower cigarette prices are associated with less use of marijuana.
most of the available evidence.
questions.answer: most of the available evidence.

questions.question: Most studies indicate that tobacco and marijuana tend to be
options: substitutes.
complements.
unrelated because one good is legal while the other one is illegal.
inferior goods.
questions.answer: complements.

questions.question: Opponents of cigarette taxes often argue that tobacco and marijuana are substitutes so that high cigarette prices
options: encourage marijuana use, and the evidence supports this argument.
encourage marijuana use, but the evidence does not support this argument.
discourage marijuana use, and the evidence supports this argument.
discourage marijuana use, but the evidence does not support this argument.
questions.answer: encourage marijuana use, but the evidence does not support this argument.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-7. The graphs show the demand for cigarettes. In Panel (a), the arrows are consistent with which of the following events?
options: The price of marijuana, a complement to cigarettes, increased.
Mandatory health warnings were placed on cigarette packages.
Several foreign countries banned U.S. cigarettes in their countries.
A tax was placed on cigarettes.
questions.answer: A tax was placed on cigarettes.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-7. The graphs show the demand for cigarettes. In Panel (a), the arrows are consistent with which of the following events?
options: Tobacco and marijuana are complements, and the price of marijuana decreased.
Tobacco is a "gateway drug," and the price of marijuana increased.
The price of cigarettes increased.
The arrows are consistent with all of these events.
questions.answer: The price of cigarettes increased.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-7. The graphs show the demand for cigarettes. In Panel (b), the arrows are consistent with which of the following events?
options: an increase in the price of cigarettes
placing a tax on cigarettes
the prohibition of cigarette advertisements on television
decreasing the price of marijuana, given that tobacco and marijuana are complements
questions.answer: the prohibition of cigarette advertisements on television

questions.question: The quantity supplied of a good is the amount that
options: buyers are willing and able to purchase.
sellers are able to produce.
buyers and sellers agree will be brought to market.
sellers are willing and able to sell.
questions.answer: sellers are willing and able to sell.

questions.question: If the price of a good is low,
options: firms would increase profit by increasing output.
the quantity supplied of the good could be zero.
the supply curve for the good will shift to the left.
firms can and should raise the price of the product.
questions.answer: the quantity supplied of the good could be zero.

questions.question: A decrease in the price of a good will
options: increase supply.
decrease supply.
increase quantity supplied.
decrease quantity supplied.
questions.answer: decrease quantity supplied.

questions.question: An increase in the price of a good will
options: increase supply.
decrease supply.
increase quantity supplied.
decrease quantity supplied.
questions.answer: increase quantity supplied.

questions.question: When the price of a good or service changes,
options: the demand curve shifts in the opposite direction.
the supply curve shifts in the opposite direction.
the supply curve shifts in the same direction.
there is a movement along a given supply curve.
questions.answer: there is a movement along a given supply curve.

questions.question: A movement along the supply curve might be caused by a change in
options: production technology.
input prices.
expectations about future prices.
the price of the good or service that is being supplied.
questions.answer: the price of the good or service that is being supplied.

questions.question: Holding the nonprice determinants of supply constant, a change in price would
options: result in either a decrease in supply or an increase in supply.
result in a movement along a stationary supply curve.
result in a shift of demand.
have no effect on the quantity supplied.
questions.answer: result in a movement along a stationary supply curve.

questions.question: An increase in the price of a good would
options: increase the supply of the good.
increase the amount purchased by buyers.
give producers an incentive to produce more.
decrease both the quantity demanded of the good and the quantity supplied of the good.
questions.answer: give producers an incentive to produce more.

questions.question: An increase in the price of oranges would lead to
options: an increased supply of oranges.
a reduction in the prices of inputs used in orange production.
an increased demand for oranges.
a movement up and to the right along the supply curve for oranges.
questions.answer: a movement up and to the right along the supply curve for oranges.

questions.question: An increase in quantity supplied
options: results in a movement downward and to the left along a fixed supply curve.
results in a movement upward and to the right along a fixed supply curve.
shifts the supply curve to the left.
shifts the supply curve to the right.
questions.answer: results in a movement upward and to the right along a fixed supply curve.

questions.question: A decrease in quantity supplied
options: results in a movement downward and to the left along a fixed supply curve.
results in a movement upward and to the right along a fixed supply curve.
shifts the supply curve to the left.
shifts the supply curve to the right.
questions.answer: results in a movement downward and to the left along a fixed supply curve.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-8. The movement from Point A to Point B represents a(n)
options: shift in the supply curve.
decrease in the quantity supplied.
increase in the quantity supplied.
Both a) and b) are correct.
questions.answer: decrease in the quantity supplied.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-8. The movement from Point A to Point B represents a(n)
options: increase in the price.
decrease in the quantity supplied.
shift in the supply curve.
Both a) and b) are correct.
questions.answer: decrease in the quantity supplied.

questions.question: "Other things equal, when the price of a good rises, the quantity supplied of the good also rises, and when the price falls, the quantity supplied falls as well." This relationship between price and quantity supplied
options: is referred to as the law of supply.
applies only to a few goods in the economy.
is represented by a downward-sloping supply curve.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: is referred to as the law of supply.

questions.question: The law of supply states that, other things equal, when the price of a good
options: falls, the supply of the good rises.
rises, the quantity supplied of the good rises.
rises, the supply of the good falls.
falls, the quantity supplied of the good rises.
questions.answer: rises, the quantity supplied of the good rises.

questions.question: The law of supply states that, other things equal, an increase in
options: price causes quantity supplied to increase.
price causes quantity supplied to decrease.
quantity supplied causes price to increase.
quantity supplied causes price to decrease.
questions.answer: price causes quantity supplied to increase.

questions.question: Other things equal, when the price of a good falls, the
options: quantity supplied of the good increases.
supply decreases.
quantity supplied of the good decreases.
demand increases.
questions.answer: quantity supplied of the good decreases.

questions.question: Which of these statements best represents the law of supply?
options: When input prices increase, sellers produce less of the good.
When production technology improves, sellers produce less of the good.
When the price of a good decreases, sellers produce less of the good.
When sellers' supplies of a good increase, the price of the good increases.
questions.answer: When the price of a good decreases, sellers produce less of the good.

questions.question: A supply curve slopes upward because
options: as more is produced, total cost of production falls.
an increase in input prices increases supply.
the quantity supplied of most goods and services increases over time.
an increase in price gives producers an incentive to supply a larger quantity.
questions.answer: an increase in price gives producers an incentive to supply a larger quantity.

questions.question: Which of the following demonstrates the law of supply?
options: When leather became more expensive, belt producers decreased their supply of belts.
When car production technology improved, car producers increased their supply of cars.
When sweater producers expected sweater prices to rise in the near future, they decreased their current supply of sweaters.
When ketchup prices rose, ketchup sellers increased their quantity supplied of ketchup.
questions.answer: When ketchup prices rose, ketchup sellers increased their quantity supplied of ketchup.

questions.question: The following table contains a supply schedule for a good. Price Quantity Supplied $10 100 $20 Q1 If the law of supply applies to this good, then Q1 could be
A supply schedule is a table that shows the relationship between
options: price and quantity supplied.
input costs and quantity supplied.
quantity demanded and quantity supplied.
profit and quantity supplied.
questions.answer: price and quantity supplied.

questions.question: Which of the following is not held constant in a supply schedule?
options: production technology
the price of the good
the prices of inputs
expectations
questions.answer: the price of the good

questions.question: The difference between a supply schedule and a supply curve is that a supply schedule
options: incorporates demand and a supply curve does not.
incorporates profit and a supply curve does not.
can shift, but a supply curve cannot shift.
is a table, and a supply curve is drawn on a graph.
questions.answer: is a table, and a supply curve is drawn on a graph.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-9. The movement from point A to point B on the graph is called
options: a decrease in supply.
an increase in supply.
an increase in the quantity supplied.
a decrease in the quantity supplied.
questions.answer: an increase in the quantity supplied.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-9. The movement from point A to point B on the graph is caused by
options: a decrease in the price of the good.
an increase in the price of the good.
an advance in production technology.
a decrease in input prices.
questions.answer: an increase in the price of the good.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-9. The movement from point A to point B on the graph represents
options: an increased willingness and ability on the part of suppliers to supply the good at each possible price.
an increase in the number of suppliers.
a decrease in the price of a relevant input.
an increase in the price of the good that is being supplied and the suppliers' responses to that price change.
questions.answer: an increase in the price of the good that is being supplied and the suppliers' responses to that price change.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-10. Which of the following would cause the supply curve to shift from Supply A to Supply C in the market for tennis racquets?
options: an increase in the price of tennis balls
an expectation by firms that the price of tennis racquets will increase in the very near future
a decrease in the price of tennis racquet strings
a decrease in the number of firms selling tennis racquets
questions.answer: a decrease in the price of tennis racquet strings

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-10. Which of the following would cause the supply curve to shift from Supply A to Supply C in the market for winter coats?
options: an increase in the price of winter coats
a decrease in the number of firms selling winter coats
a decrease in the price of zippers and snaps
a decrease in the price of winter hats and gloves
questions.answer: a decrease in the price of zippers and snaps

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-10. Which of the following would cause the supply curve to shift from Supply B to Supply A in the market for tennis racquets?
options: a decrease in the price of tennis balls
an expectation by firms that the price of tennis racquets will increase in the very near future
a decrease in the price of tennis racquet strings
an improvement in technology that allows firms to use less labor in the production of tennis racquets
questions.answer: an expectation by firms that the price of tennis racquets will increase in the very near future

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-10. Which of the following would cause the supply curve to shift from Supply B to Supply A in the market for disposable ballpoint pens?
options: a decrease in the price of disposable ballpoint pens
an increase in the price of fountain pens
an increase in the price of ink
an improvement in technology that allows firms to use less labor in the production of disposable ballpoint pens
questions.answer: an increase in the price of ink

questions.question: The supply curve for a good is a line that relates
options: profit and quantity supplied.
quantity supplied and quantity demanded.
price and quantity supplied.
price and profit.
questions.answer: price and quantity supplied.

questions.question: The line that relates the price of a good and the quantity supplied of that good is called the supply
options: schedule, and it usually slopes upward.
schedule, and it usually slopes downward.
curve, and it usually slopes upward.
curve, and it usually slopes downward.
questions.answer: curve, and it usually slopes upward.

questions.question: When we move along a given supply curve,
options: only price is held constant.
technology and price are held constant.
all nonprice determinants of supply are held constant.
all determinants of quantity supplied are held constant.
questions.answer: all nonprice determinants of supply are held constant.

questions.question: Once the supply curve for a product or service is drawn, it
options: remains stable over time.
can shift either rightward or leftward.
is possible to move along the curve, but the curve will not shift.
tends to become steeper over time.
questions.answer: can shift either rightward or leftward.

questions.question: If something happens to alter the quantity supplied at any given price, then
options: we move along the supply curve.
the supply curve shifts.
the supply curve becomes steeper.
the supply curve becomes flatter.
questions.answer: the supply curve shifts.

questions.question: An increase in supply is represented by a
options: movement downward and to the left along a supply curve.
movement upward and to the right along a supply curve.
rightward shift of a supply curve.
leftward shift of a supply curve.
questions.answer: rightward shift of a supply curve.

questions.question: A decrease in supply is represented by a
options: movement downward and to the left along a supply curve.
movement upward and to the right along a supply curve.
rightward shift of a supply curve.
leftward shift of a supply curve.
questions.answer: leftward shift of a supply curve.

questions.question: A leftward shift of a supply curve is called a(n)
options: increase in supply.
decrease in supply.
decrease in quantity supplied.
increase in quantity supplied.
questions.answer: decrease in supply.

questions.question: A rightward shift of a supply curve is called a(n)
options: increase in supply.
decrease in supply.
decrease in quantity supplied.
increase in quantity supplied.
questions.answer: increase in supply.

questions.question: A movement upward and to the right along a supply curve is called a(n)
options: increase in supply.
decrease in supply.
decrease in quantity supplied.
increase in quantity supplied.
questions.answer: increase in quantity supplied.

questions.question: A movement downward and to the left along a supply curve is called a(n)
options: increase in supply.
decrease in supply.
decrease in quantity supplied.
increase in quantity supplied.
questions.answer: decrease in quantity supplied.

questions.question: When quantity supplied decreases at every possible price, we know that the supply curve has
options: shifted to the left.
shifted to the right.
not shifted; rather, we have moved along the supply curve to a new point on the same curve.
not shifted; rather, the supply curve has become flatter.
questions.answer: shifted to the left.

questions.question: When quantity supplied increases at every possible price, we know that the supply curve has
options: shifted to the left.
shifted to the right.
not shifted; rather, we have moved along the supply curve to a new point on the same curve.
not shifted; rather, the supply curve has become flatter.
questions.answer: shifted to the right.

questions.question: The supply curve for milk
options: shifts when the price of milk changes because the price of milk is measured on the vertical axis of the graph.
shifts when the price of milk changes because the quantity supplied of milk is measured on the horizontal axis of the graph.
does not shift when the price of milk changes because the price of milk is measured on the vertical axis of the graph.
does not shift when the price of milk changes because the price of milk is measured on the horizontal axis of the graph.
questions.answer: does not shift when the price of milk changes because the price of milk is measured on the vertical axis of the graph.

questions.question: Which of the following changes would not shift the supply curve for a good or service?
options: a change in production technology
a change in the price of the good or service
a change in expectations about the future price of the good or service
a change in input prices
