questions.answer: a change in the price of the good or service

questions.question: Which of the following would not shift the supply curve for mp3 players?
options: an increase in the price of mp3 players
a decrease in the number of sellers of mp3 players
an increase in the price of plastic, an input into the production of mp3 players
an improvement in the technology used to produce mp3 players
questions.answer: an increase in the price of mp3 players

questions.question: Which of the following events would cause a movement upward and to the right along the supply curve for mangos?
options: The number of sellers of mangos increases.
There is an advance in technology that reduces the cost of producing mangos.
The price of fertilizer decreases, and fertilizer is an input in the production of mangos.
The price of mangos rises.
questions.answer: The price of mangos rises.

questions.question: The sum of all the individual supply curves for a product is called
options: total supply.
market supply.
aggregate supply.
total output.
questions.answer: market supply.

questions.question: The market supply curve
options: is found by vertically adding the individual supply curves.
slopes downward.
represents the sum of the prices that all the sellers are willing to accept for a given quantity of the good.
represents the sum of the quantities supplied by all the sellers at each price of the good.
questions.answer: represents the sum of the quantities supplied by all the sellers at each price of the good.

questions.question: In a market, to find the total amount supplied at a particular price, we must
options: sum the quantities that individual firms are willing and able to supply at that price.
calculate the average of the quantities that individual firms are willing and able to supply at that price.
sum the costs that individual firms incur to supply the product at that price.
account for all determinants of demand.
questions.answer: sum the quantities that individual firms are willing and able to supply at that price.

questions.question: A market supply curve is determined by
options: vertically summing individual supply curves.
horizontally summing individual supply curves.
finding the average quantity supplied by sellers at each possible price.
finding the average price at which sellers are willing and able to sell a particular quantity of the good.
questions.answer: horizontally summing individual supply curves.

questions.question: A market supply curve shows
options: the total quantity supplied at all possible prices.
the average quantity supplied by producers at all possible prices.
how quantity supplied changes when consumer income changes.
suppliers' responses, in terms of the amounts they will supply, to the demands of buyers.
questions.answer: the total quantity supplied at all possible prices.

questions.question: A market supply curve shows how the total quantity supplied of a good varies as
options: production technology varies.
price varies.
input prices vary.
demand varies.
questions.answer: price varies.

questions.question: Suppose there are five suppliers of ice cream in the town of Summerville. If we add the respective quantities that each firm would produce at each of the five ice cream parlors when the price of ice cream is $2 per scoop, $2.50 per scoop, and $3 per scoop, and so forth, we have found the
options: market demand curve.
market supply curve.
equilibrium curve.
surplus or shortage depending on market conditions.
questions.answer: market supply curve.

questions.question: Refer to Table 4-4. Which supply schedules obey the law of supply?
options: Firm A's only
Firm B's, Firm C's, and Firm D's only
Firm A's and Firm C's only
Firm B's and Firm D's only
questions.answer: Firm B's and Firm D's only

questions.question: Refer to Table 4-4. If these are the only four sellers in the market, then the market quantity supplied at a price of $4 is
options: 4 units.
7.5 units.
10 units.
30 units.
questions.answer: 30 units.

questions.question: Refer to Table 4-4. If these are the only four sellers in the market, then the market quantity supplied at a price of $10 is
options: 3 units.
11 units.
25 units.
44 units.
questions.answer: 44 units.

questions.question: Refer to Table 4-4. If these are the only four sellers in the market, then when the price increases from $6 to $8, the market quantity supplied
options: increases by 0.5 units.
increases by 2 units.
decreases by 4 units.
increases by 42 units.
questions.answer: increases by 2 units.

questions.question: Refer to Table 4-4. If these are the only four sellers in the market, then when the price decreases from $4 to $2, the market quantity supplied
options: increases by 10 units.
decreases by 10 units.
decreases by 20 units.
decreases by 30 units.
questions.answer: decreases by 10 units.

questions.question: Refer to Table 4-5. If these are the only four sellers in the market, then the market quantity supplied at a price of $4 is
options: 4 units.
5 units.
20 units.
80 units.
questions.answer: 20 units.

questions.question: Refer to Table 4-5. If these are the only four sellers in the market, then the market quantity supplied at a price of $8 is
options: 10 units.
20 units.
32 units.
40 units.
questions.answer: 40 units.

questions.question: Refer to Table 4-5. If these are the only four sellers in the market, then when the price decreases from $10 to $8, the market quantity supplied decreases by
options: 2.5 units.
4 units.
10 units.
50 units.
questions.answer: 10 units.

questions.question: Refer to Table 4-5. If these are the only four sellers in the market, then when the price increases from $4 to $6, the market quantity supplied
options: decreases by 10 units.
decreases by 20 units.
increases by 10 units.
increases by 20 units.
questions.answer: increases by 10 units.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-11. If these are the only two sellers in the market, then the market quantity supplied at a price of $4 is
options: 6 units.
7 units.
8 units.
14 units.
questions.answer: 14 units.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-11. If these are the only two sellers in the market, then the market quantity supplied at a price of $6 is
options: 2 units.
10 units.
12 units.
22 units.
questions.answer: 22 units.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-11. If these are the only two sellers in the market, then the market quantity supplied at a price of $8 is
options: 14 units.
15 units.
16 units.
29 units.
questions.answer: 29 units.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-12. If Producer A and Producer B are the only producers in the market, then the market quantity supplied when the price is $4 is
options: 4 units.
8 units.
12 units.
16 units.
questions.answer: 12 units.

questions.question: The supply curve for portable charcoal grills shifts
options: only when production technology changes.
when a determinant of the supply of portable charcoal grills other than the price of portable charcoal grills changes.
when any determinant of the supply of portable charcoal grills changes.
only when the number of sellers of portable charcoal grills changes.
questions.answer: when a determinant of the supply of portable charcoal grills other than the price of portable charcoal grills changes.

questions.question: Lead is an important input in the production of crystal. If the price of lead decreases, then we would expect the supply of
options: crystal to be unaffected.
crystal to decrease.
crystal to increase.
lead to increase.
questions.answer: crystal to increase.

questions.question: Suppose you make jewelry. If the price of gold falls, then we would expect you to
options: be willing and able to produce less jewelry than before at each possible price.
be willing and able to produce more jewelry than before at each possible price.
face a greater demand for your jewelry.
face a weaker demand for your jewelry.
questions.answer: be willing and able to produce more jewelry than before at each possible price.

questions.question: Workers at a bicycle assembly plant currently earn the mandatory minimum wage. If the federal government increases the minimum wage by $1.00 per hour, then it is likely that the
options: demand for bicycle assembly workers will increase.
supply of bicycles will shift to the right.
supply of bicycles will shift to the left.
firm must increase output to maintain profit levels.
questions.answer: supply of bicycles will shift to the left.

questions.question: Suppose there is an increase in the price of steel. We would expect the supply curve for steel beams to
options: shift rightward.
shift leftward.
become flatter.
remain unchanged.
questions.answer: shift leftward.

questions.question: Wheat is the main input in the production of flour. If the price of wheat decreases, then we would expect the
options: demand for flour to increase.
demand for flour to decrease.
supply of flour to increase.
supply of flour to decrease.
questions.answer: supply of flour to increase.

questions.question: Matthew bakes apple pies that he sells at the local farmer's market. If the price of apples increases, the
options: supply curve for Matthew's pies will increase.
supply curve for Matthew's pies will decrease.
demand curve for Matthew's pies will increase.
demand curve for Matthew's pies will decrease.
questions.answer: supply curve for Matthew's pies will decrease.

questions.question: Suppose an increase in the price of rubber coincides with an advance in the technology of tire production. As a result of these two events, the demand for tires
options: decreases, and the supply of tires increases.
is unaffected, and the supply of tires decreases.
is unaffected, and the supply of tires increases.
None of the above is necessarily correct.
questions.answer: None of the above is necessarily correct.

questions.question: A improvement in production technology will shift the
options: supply curve to the right.
supply curve to the left.
demand curve to the right.
demand curve to the left.
questions.answer: supply curve to the right.

questions.question: An improvement in production technology will
options: increase a firm's costs and increase its supply.
increase a firm's costs and decrease its supply.
decrease a firm's costs and increase its supply.
decrease a firm's costs and decrease its supply.
questions.answer: decrease a firm's costs and increase its supply.

questions.question: If car manufacturers begin using new labor-saving technology on their assembly lines, we would not expect
options: a smaller quantity of labor to be used.
the supply of cars to increase.
the firms' costs to fall.
individual car manufacturers to move up and to the right along their individual supply curves.
questions.answer: individual car manufacturers to move up and to the right along their individual supply curves.

questions.question: Which of the following might cause the supply curve for an inferior good to shift to the right?
options: an increase in input prices
a decrease in consumer income
an improvement in production technology that makes production of the good more profitable
a decrease in the number of sellers in the market
questions.answer: an improvement in production technology that makes production of the good more profitable

questions.question: Ashley bakes bread that she sells at the local farmer's market. If she purchases a new convection oven that reduces the costs of baking bread, the
options: supply curve for Ashley's bread will increase.
supply curve for Ashley's bread will decrease.
demand curve for Ashley's bread will increase.
demand curve for Ashley's bread will decrease.
questions.answer: supply curve for Ashley's bread will increase.

questions.question: Today, producers changed their expectations about the future. This change
options: can cause a movement along a supply curve.
can affect future supply, but not today's supply.
can affect today's supply.
cannot affect either today's supply or future supply.
questions.answer: can affect today's supply.

questions.question: If suppliers expect the price of their product to fall in the future, then they will
options: decrease supply now.
increase supply now.
decrease supply in the future but not now.
increase supply in the future but not now.
questions.answer: increase supply now.

questions.question: If sellers expect higher basket prices in the near future, the current
options: supply of baskets will increase.
supply of baskets will decrease.
supply of baskets will be unaffected.
demand for baskets will decrease.
questions.answer: supply of baskets will decrease.

questions.question: Today's supply curve for gasoline could shift in response to a change in
options: today's price of gasoline.
the expected future price of gasoline.
the number of buyers of gasoline.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: the expected future price of gasoline.

questions.question: A dress manufacturer recently has come to expect higher prices for dresses in the near future. We would expect
options: the dress manufacturer to supply more dresses now than it was supplying previously.
the dress manufacturer to supply fewer dresses now than it was supplying previously.
the demand for this manufacturer's dresses to fall.
no change in the dress manufacturer's current supply; instead, future supply will be affected.
questions.answer: the dress manufacturer to supply fewer dresses now than it was supplying previously.

questions.question: Recent forest fires in the western states are expected to cause the price of lumber to rise in the next six months. As a result, we can expect the supply of lumber to
options: fall in six months but not now.
increase in six months when the price goes up.
fall now.
increase now to meet as much demand as possible.
questions.answer: fall now.

questions.question: Funsters, Inc., the largest toy company in the country, sells its most popular doll for $15. It has just learned that its leading competitor, Toysorama, is mass-producing an excellent copy and plans to flood the market with their $5 doll in six weeks. Funsters should
options: "fight fire with fire" by decreasing supply of its doll for six weeks and then increasing the supply.
increase the supply of its doll now before the other doll hits the market.
increase the price of its doll now.
discontinue its doll.
questions.answer: increase the supply of its doll now before the other doll hits the market.

questions.question: Which of the following is a determinant of the market supply curve but not a determinant of an individual seller's supply?
options: production technology
expectations
input prices
the number of sellers
questions.answer: the number of sellers

questions.question: If the number of sellers in a market increases, then the
options: demand in that market will increase.
supply in that market will increase.
supply in that market will decrease.
demand in that market will decrease.
questions.answer: supply in that market will increase.

questions.question: A decrease in the number of sellers in the market causes
options: the supply curve to shift to the left.
the supply curve to shift to the right.
a movement up and to the right along a stationary supply curve.
a movement downward and to the left along a stationary supply curve.
questions.answer: the supply curve to shift to the left.

questions.question: An increase in which of the following would shift the supply curve for gasoline to the right?
options: demand for gasoline
price of gasoline
number of producers of gasoline
price of oil, an input into the production of gasoline
questions.answer: number of producers of gasoline

questions.question: Which of the following events could cause an increase in the supply of ceiling fans?
options: The number of sellers of ceiling fans increases.
There is an increase in the price of air conditioners, and consumers regard air conditioners and ceiling fans as substitutes.
There is an increase in the price of the motor that powers ceiling fans.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: The number of sellers of ceiling fans increases.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-13. The shift from S to S' is called a(n)
options: decrease in supply.
decrease in quantity supplied.
increase in supply.
increase in quantity supplied.
questions.answer: increase in supply.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-13. The shift from S to S' could be caused by an
options: increase in the price of the good.
improvement in production technology.
increase in income.
increase in input prices.
questions.answer: improvement in production technology.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-13. The shift from S to S' in the market for peaches could be caused by a(n)
options: increase in the price of peaches.
decrease in the price of pears.
increase in income.
decrease in the labor costs of the workers who pick peaches.
questions.answer: decrease in the labor costs of the workers who pick peaches.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-13. The shift from S' to S in the market for chocolate cake could be caused by a(n)
options: decrease in the number of commercial bakers.
improvement in oven technology.
decrease in the price of butter.
decrease in the price of chocolate cake.
questions.answer: decrease in the number of commercial bakers.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 4-13. If the supply curves that are drawn represent supply curves for single-family residential houses, then the movement from S to S' could be caused by a(n)
options: increase in the price of apartments which are a substitute for single-family houses for many people looking for a place to live.
newly-formed expectation by house-builders that prices of houses will increase significantly in the next six months.
decrease in the price of lumber.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: decrease in the price of lumber.

questions.question: The unique point at which the supply and demand curves intersect is called
options: market harmony.
coincidence.
equivalence.
equilibrium.
questions.answer: equilibrium.

questions.question: The dictionary defines equilibrium as a situation in which forces
options: are in balance.
are the same.
clash.
remain constant.
questions.answer: are in balance.

questions.question: At the equilibrium price, the quantity of the good that buyers are willing and able to buy
options: is greater than the quantity that sellers are willing and able to sell.
exactly equals the quantity that sellers are willing and able to sell.
is less than the quantity that sellers are willing and able to sell.
Either a) or c) could be correct.
questions.answer: exactly equals the quantity that sellers are willing and able to sell.

questions.question: Another term for equilibrium price is
options: dynamic price.
market-clearing price.
quantity-defining price.
balance price.

questions.question: In any economic system, scarce resources have to be allocated among competing uses. Market economies harness the forces of
options: government to allocate scarce resources.
supply and demand to allocate scarce resources.
credit cards to allocate scarce resources.

questions.answer: supply and demand to allocate scarce resources.

prices.
questions.answer: prices.

questions.answer: The prices of food and the wages of farmers would adjust.
